solution_line_template: Twice as many chocolates as she ate the first day is {multiplier_twice}*{chocolates_day1}=<<{multiplier_twice}*{chocolates_day1}={twice_day1}>>{twice_day1} chocolates.
And three less than twice as many chocolates as she ate the first day is {twice_day1}-{less_than_twice}=<<{twice_day1}-{less_than_twice}={chocolates_day2}>>{chocolates_day2} chocolates.
Two less than the number she ate on the first day is {chocolates_day1}-{less_than_day1_day3}=<<{chocolates_day1}-{less_than_day1_day3}={chocolates_day3}>>{chocolates_day3} chocolates.
One less than she ate the third day is {chocolates_day3}-{less_than_day3_day4}=<<{chocolates_day3}-{less_than_day3_day4}={chocolates_day4}>>{chocolates_day4} chocolate.

By the end of the fourth day, {chocolates_day1}+{chocolates_day2}+{chocolates_day3}+{chocolates_day4}=<<{chocolates_day1}+{chocolates_day2}+{chocolates_day3}+{chocolates_day4}={total_eaten}>>{total_eaten} chocolates had been eaten.
Thus, on the fifth day, {initial_chocolates}-{total_eaten}=<<{initial_chocolates}-{total_eaten}={remaining_chocolates}>>{remaining_chocolates} chocolates remained uneaten.
